papers.title: Orofacial Pain: How to Evaluate and Treat, Part 1
papers.abstract: ABSTRACT: A number of nondental conditions may cause significant oral pain. Pain associated with temporal arteritis is localized to the maxillary posterior teeth, the maxilla, or the frontal-temple region. This pain is often associated with exquisite tenderness of the scalp and face. The pain of trigeminal neuralgia is typically felt in the anterior maxillary or mandibular anterior teeth; it radiates along the mandible toward or into the ear on the ipsilateral side of the trigger. Pain may remit for months or years but is often severe when it recurs. Burning mouth syndrome preferentially affects postmenopausal women older than 50 years; one half to two thirds of patients experience spontaneous remission within 6 to 7 years, with or without treatment. The pain of postherpetic neuralgia is unilateral and restricted to the affected dermatome; it may be aggravated by mechanical contact or chewing.

papers.title: Acute cough
papers.abstract: Acute cough is defined as a cough lasting less than 3 weeks. Few studies have evaluated the incidence of specific causes of acute cough, but based on clinical experience, the majority of cases are due to acute upper respiratory tract infections.1 In addition, coughs of non-infectious aetiologies, including allergic disorders, physical factors and drugs (ACE inhibitors) start out as acute coughs but become prolonged or chronic as time passes. Even after acute symptoms of a infection have resolved, a ‘post-infectious cough’ often develops. This is classified as a persistent cough (see Fig. 3.1). The diagnosis of acute cough is based on clinical findings, including history, physical examination and laboratory tests. Sudden cough is sometimes associated with life-threatening conditions, and these must be ruled out at initial evaluation (Fig. 4.1). Pulmonary embolism. Congestive heart failure. Pneumonia. Lung cancer (primary or metastatic). Pulmonary tuberculosis. Interstitial pneumonitis. Pneumothorax. These disorders are relatively easy to diagnose when typical symptoms, signs, and CXR and laboratory findings are present, but with atypical findings, diagnosis may be difficult. In pulmonary embolism, about 50% of patients have a cough, and in many cases, cough is the chief complaint.1 In patients with cough who have risk factors for pulmonary embolism, further evaluation is necessary. Also, in elderly patients with pneumonia, cough may be the only symptom, with absence of fever or other signs of inflammation. This is particularly true in aspiration pneumonia, in which aspiration itself causes a cough. Infiltrates may be absent on initial CXR, so careful follow up is required. Table 1.1 summarizes clinical findings in common causes of acute cough in adults, and Figure 1.1 is a flow chart for diagnosis of acute cough. Flowchart for diagnosis of acute cough. ACE, angiotensin converting enzyme; CRP, C-reactive protein; GERD, gastro-esophageal reflux disease; GI, gastrointestinal; HRCT, high-resolution computed tomography. The common cold is usually a mild self-resolving condition. Symptoms often include rhinorrhoea, nasal stuffiness, sore throat, lacrimation and hoarseness, which may or may not be accompanied by fever. Chest findings on physical examination are usually normal. The incidence of the common cold is high in younger people and decreases with ageing.2 However, in elderly patients who are immunocompromised or have other complications, serious consequences can develop. Most of the causative organisms are viruses, including rhinovirus in 30–40%, corona virus in 10–20% and parainfluenza virus in 10–15% of cases.3 Other causes include RS virus and adenovirus. In clinical practice, the exact aetiology is rarely known at initial evaluation, but no further identification is generally necessary. In the common cold, cough is due to postnasal drip with nasal symptoms and is often productive,1 but more prolonged coughs are usually dry. There may be purulent sputum, but this does not always indicate bacterial infection. Coughs range from mild to severe. Even in viral infections, patients may have bronchitis-like symptoms, with severe coughing and retrosternal pain. The common cold is usually self-resolving and treated symptomatically without specific therapy. So-called cold preparations to relieve symptoms are often overrated, and long-term use should be avoided. Symptoms like fever are a host defence to viral infection, so indiscriminate use of antipyretic analgesic drugs should also be avoided. Although not indicated for the common cold, antimicrobials should be considered in patients with secondary bacterial infections or pharyngitis due to group A haemolytic streptococcus.4 Judicious use is recommended to prevent adverse effects and the emergence of resistant bacteria. Cough suppressants can be used for symptomatic treatment. Influenza typically occurs in the winter, and during outbreaks, is one of the most common reasons for visits to clinics and emergency rooms. As compared with the common cold, symptoms such as fever, headache, arthralgia and myalgia are more prominent. Clinical features of influenza vary with patient age. In older patients, upper respiratory symptoms like rhinorrhoea, nasal congestion and sore throat are less common than in children and younger adults, whereas lower respiratory symptoms like cough and sputum production and general symptoms like loss of appetite are more common. Clinical diagnosis of influenza is easy during outbreaks in the winter. To confirm the diagnosis, rapid diagnostic kits to detect viral antigens are commercially available. These tests are convenient, take only 15–25 min to perform, and are useful at the bedside and in outpatient settings. The development of neuraminidase inhibitors has revolutionized the treatment of influenza. By blocking neuraminidase activity, these drugs inhibit the release of budding virus from cell surfaces. Zanamivir (Relenza®) and oseltamivir (Tamiflu®) are currently approved. If started within 48 h after symptom onset, these drugs can shorten the duration of major symptoms by at least 1 day. Amantadine exerts its antiviral effect by blocking M2 ion channels and preventing uncoating of viruses incorporated into the endosomes of infected cells. This is effective only against type A influenza viruses. Because of the high rate of emergence of resistant viruses, amantadine should not be used for treatment in otherwise healthy individuals. Its use should be limited to severe infections or in high-risk patients. In addition to antiviral agents, antipyretics and antitussives for symptomatic treatment and antimicrobials for secondary bacterial infections can be prescribed. In Japan, a government assistance programme has helped to improve the influenza vaccination rate in elderly persons. Vaccination is recommended in older individuals and other high-risk patients.5 The mode of transmission of M. pneumoniae from infected to other individuals is by droplets or direct contact. In recent years, the epidemics that previously occurred every 4 years have decreased. Mycoplasma infections occur mostly in children and young adults, but rarely in older individuals. They are characterized by upper respiratory inflammation, bronchitis and pneumonia. Systemic complications are also frequent. The incubation period is 2–3 weeks, and initial symptoms include fever (high fever), generalized malaise and headache. Cough usually begins 3–5 days after the appearance of initial symptoms, gradually worsens as the disease progresses and often lasts 3–4 weeks after the fever subsides. Therefore, diagnosis and treatment in some cases is for an acute cough up to 3 weeks, and in other cases, for a persistent cough. The cough is initially dry, but especially in older children and young adults, the cough may later become productive, and asthma-like symptoms are relatively common. Some patients have asthma at an early stage of infection. Systemic symptoms are usually mild to moderate and have a benign course, but severe progression from pneumonia to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) may occur. Laboratory findings include a normal or increased leukocyte count, elevated sedimentation rate, at least a moderately positive CRP, and transient elevations in serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT). In most cases, when cough becomes persistent, the CRP becomes negative. Methods to detect M. pneumoniae include culture isolation, antigen assays and PCR. For culture isolation, specimens from throat swabs, sputum, or airway secretions are cultured on PPLO medium. Commercial antigen detection kits use DNA probes or direct immunofluorescence. PCR is available in a limited number of facilities. Serum diagnostic tests are generally used. Specific serum antibody tests include complement fixation, indirect and passive haemagglutination and particle agglutination. In paired serum specimens, at least a fourfold rise between acute and convalescent titres measured 2–3 weeks later is considered diagnostic of infection. For diagnosis using a single serum specimen, an antibody titre of ≥64 by complement fixation or ≥320 to 640 by indirect haemagglutination is necessary. Recently, a rapid assay kit using immunochromatography to detect IgM antibodies, which increase early during infection, has been developed for clinical use (ImmunoCard Mycoplasma IgM). This convenient and highly useful test can be used in outpatient settings to diagnose infection as early as one week after onset. Treatment with macrolide antibiotics is most effective, but tetracyclines and some quinolone drugs can also be used. In mild infections, oral administration of a newer-generation macrolide is appropriate. but in moderate or severe infections, patients should be hospitalized and treated with Erythrocin by i.v. infusion. Because relapse can occur, treatment should be continued for 7–10 days. Chlamydial respiratory infections include Chlamydophila pneumoniae respiratory tract infections, psittacosis and Chlamydia trachomatis pneumonia in newborns and infants. Chlamydophila pneumoniae is an obligate intracellular bacterium that causes infection in humans. Human-to-human transmission of infection is through the expulsion of droplets by coughing. Unlike M. pneumoniae, infection is common both in children and older adults.6 Sporadic outbreaks of cold symptoms due to this organism occur in families, child-care centres and schools, and in Japan, outbreaks have also been reported in nursing homes. Chlamydophila pneumoniae has a latent period of 3–4 weeks and can cause acute upper respiratory infection, sinusitis, bronchitis, exacerbation of infections in COPD and pneumonia. In upper respiratory infection and bronchitis, dry cough is the main symptom, with severe cough often lasting 3–4 weeks. Therefore, as in Mycoplasma infections, diagnosis and treatment in some cases is for an acute cough up to 3 weeks, and in other cases, for a persistent cough. The cough is dry in early infection but later often becomes productive. Asthma-like symptoms are relatively common, and some patients have asthma during the acute phase. However, much remains unclear about the associated airway hypersensitivity or increased cough sensitivity. Fever higher than 38°C generally does not occur. On the other hand, asymptomatic infection is not uncommon. The infection is usually self-resolving, and specific symptoms such as sore throat, rhinorrhoea, hoarseness and dyspnoea are rare. In pneumonia, the clinical findings are similar to those in atypical pneumonia. Laboratory findings include a normal or slightly increased leukocyte count, elevated sedimentation rate, and at least a moderately positive CRP. In most cases, when cough becomes persistent, the CRP becomes negative. Specific diagnostic tests include pathogen detection from throat swabs, but isolation is difficult, so enzyme immunoassay (group-specific antigen detection kits) and DNA methods (PCR) are used. The micro-immunofluorescence (micro-IF) test to measure anti-C. pneumoniae antibody is the ‘gold’ standard for serodiagnosis, but this is only available in a limited number of facilities. A specific (IgG, IgA, IgM) antibody kit (Hitazyme C. pneumoniae) using ELISA is commonly used. Serodiagnosis requires a significant rise in antibody titres in paired serum specimens or a positive IgM. In adults, tetracyclines (e.g. Minomycin®) are the first-line antibiotic for treatment of Chlamydophyla, but macrolides (e.g. Clarith®, Zithromac®), quinolones (e.g. Spara®) and ketolides (e.g. Ketec®) are also effective. In children and pregnant women, the first-line treatment is a macrolide. Treatment should be continued for 10 days to 2 weeks. Antitussives can be prescribed for severe cough but are often ineffective. Infection with C. pneumoniae is often self-resolving, but the organism may be present in the airways for long periods. Therefore, in patients evaluated for persistent cough with suspected infection but not previously treated with an effective antibiotic, a course of antimicrobial therapy should be considered. Psittacosis is an infection due to inhalation of Chlamydophila psittaci in the excrement of infected birds. After an incubation period of 1–2 weeks, patients typically develop a sudden high fever and cough. Headache, relative bradycardia and liver function abnormalities are also common. The cough is initially dry but later becomes productive. As compared with C. pneumoniae, persistent cough is not as common. The clinical features are typical of pneumonia, but mild upper respiratory infection and bronchitis may be present. In patients with severe pneumonia, especially if initial therapy was inappropriate, meningitis, multiorgan failure, disseminated intravascular coagulation, shock and death may occur. On initial evaluation, a history of contact with birds is important. Laboratory findings include a normal or increased leukocyte count, elevated sedimentation rate and at least a moderately positive CRP. Serum AST and ALT are also frequently elevated. Specific diagnosis includes the isolation of C. psittaci from throat swab specimens or birds. Genetic testing by PCR is used for confirmatory diagnosis but is only available in a limited number of facilities. In general, serodiagnosis is used. In psittacosis, complement fixation is used for Chlamydia group antigen but cannot identify the species. Using the micro-IF test, at least a fourfold rise in C. psittaci-specific IgG antibody in paired serum specimens or a positive IgM is diagnostic for infection. Treatment of psittacosis is generally the same as previously described for C. pneumoniae, but in fulminant cases, treatment of systemic and respiratory manifestations is required. Chlamydia trachomatis causes rhinitis, sinusitis and pneumonia in newborns and infants due to maternal–child transmission of infection during birth from mothers with C. trachomatis cervicitis. C. trachomatis is a common cause of afebrile pneumonia in newborns and infants. Common symptoms are conjunctivitis, coryza and cough. The cough is productive and asthma and dyspnoea may occur. Cough usually improves with antibiotic treatment, but if left untreated, cough can become persistent. In pneumonia, the CXR shows interstitial and diffuse lung infiltrates, sometimes with hyper expansion. The CRP is positive, with no leukocytosis; eosinophilia is often present. Pathogen detection includes culture of swabs from the nasopharynx and airway secretions, antigen assays and DNA methods. Antibody titre assays to measure serum C. trachomatis antibodies are also available. In newborns and infants with pneumonia, an increase in specific IgM antibody is useful in diagnosing C. trachomatis infection. Treatment is with macrolide antibiotics (e.g. Erythrocin®) by i.v. infusion. Pertussis is an infection caused by B. pertussis, a small Gram-negative bacillus. After inhalation of droplets into the airway and about a 7-day latent period, cold-like symptoms of rhinitis and cough (catarrhal stage) develop. This is followed by gradual worsening of coughing during the paroxysmal stage. During this stage, there is a distinctive ‘staccato’ cough with an inspiratory ‘whoop’ that is repetitive (reprise). Cough is worse at night and may be accompanied by vomiting. In infants, pertussis can be especially severe, with apnoea, seizures and impaired consciousness. The paroxysmal stage, which lasts 2–5 weeks, is followed by the convalescent stage, in which symptoms gradually resolve. In the absence of complications, the entire course of infection lasts 6–12 weeks. Infections due to Bordetella parapertussis and viruses like adenovirus also present with similar clinical findings. This is called the ‘pertussis syndrome’. Pertussis occurs most often in infants and young children less than 2 years of age, but interest has also been focused on pertussis as a cause of acute and persistent coughs in adults. Reports from Western countries indicate that 6–21% of adults with persistent cough have pertussis based on antibody assays and PCR.7–11 In addition, during outbreaks of pertussis and M. pneumoniae, the incidence of post-infectious persistent cough may be as high as 25–50%.12 In Japan, the incidence of pertussis in adults with cough is unknown, but among young adults, the rate of antibodies to pertussis toxin has increased,13 and some adults may have reinfection. In a survey conducted overseas, clinical features of pertussis did not markedly differ between adolescents and adults. In over 80% of cases, at least three of the classical features, including paroxysmal cough, post-tussive apnoea, post-tussive vomiting and whoop, were present, and the median duration of cough was 12 weeks.14 Bordetella pertussis can be cultured from sputum or nasopharyngeal mucus samples on Bordet-Gengou medium. More recently, PCR detection is also being performed. Serodiagnosis includes assay of serum B. pertussis agglutinin titres for the Yamaguchi strain and Tohama strain; assay of antifilamentous haemagglutinin (anti-FHA) antibody (ELISA, latex particle agglutination and gelatine particle agglutination); and assay of antipertussis toxin (anti-PT) antibody (ELISA, CHO cell assay). All require paired acute and convalescent sera for diagnosis. The first-line antimicrobials for treatment are macrolides, including erythromycin (e.g. Erythrocin®), clarithromycin (e.g. Clarith®, Klaricid®), roxithromycin (e.g. Rulid®) and azithromycin (e.g. Zithromac®). Treatment started 7–10 days after the onset of symptoms may not provide relief, but treatment is still recommended to prevent the spread of infection.15 Overseas, β agonists and inhaled corticosteroids are sometimes prescribed. Potent cough suppressants like codeine phosphate may be dangerous because they decrease the cough reflex, but conventional antitussive/expectorants can be used. Reinfection in adults is a potential reservoir of infection for children, and revaccination in adults has been considered.16,17 Acute rhinitis is most frequently due to the common cold. This is caused by airway viral infections, but secondary bacterial infection can occur. Symptoms include sneezing, watery nasal discharge, sore throat, fever and cough, often followed by a purulent nasal discharge, stuffiness and loss of smell. Examination of the nasal mucosa reveals congestion, swelling and copious secretions. Symptoms usually resolve in 1–4 weeks. The diagnosis is straightforward in most cases, but in children, other causes of acute infection such as measles should be considered. If symptoms are mild, it is important to include allergic rhinitis in the differential diagnosis. Symptomatic therapy is indicated in suspected viral infections. This includes rest, adequate fluid intake and antihistamines or cold preparations for symptoms such as rhinorrhoea. If the nasal discharge is purulent and secondary bacterial infection is suspected, treatment with antibiotics may be warranted. First-line treatment is a broad spectrum antibiotic effective against most common organisms, including haemolytic Streptococcus, Pneumococcus, Staphylococcus and H. influenzae. In patients with severe nasal obstruction due to mucosal congestion and swelling, vasoconstrictor nasal drops can be used as needed. Local treatment with nasal aspiration is also effective in relieving symptoms. Allergic rhinitis is a type I allergic reaction of the nasal mucosa. The three cardinal symptoms are recurrent episodes of sneezing, watery nasal discharge and nasal obstruction. The aetiology in most cases of allergic rhinitis is inhaled allergens, including mites (Dermatophagoides: major allergens in house dust), pollen (e.g. trees, grasses, weeds) and fungi. Mites and pollens are particularly common. Food allergens play a minimal role in allergic rhinitis. In allergic rhinitis due to pollen antigens, symptoms occur when the offending pollen is in the air. This is called pollinosis (seasonal allergic rhinitis). In contrast, perennial allergic rhinitis is due to dust and mite antigens present throughout the year. Patients who remain untreated may develop a stubborn cough. Exposure to grass and ragweed pollens can cause asthma. However, cedar pollen has a larger diameter and does not reach the lower airway; thus, asthma is uncommon. A detailed medical history is important to find out whether symptoms are seasonal or perennial (non-seasonal) and provide clues to the offending allergen. In perennial allergic rhinitis, the nasal mucosa is pale and oedematous, and the nasal discharge is watery. In pollinosis, the nasal mucosa is reddened and may be acutely inflamed. However, the findings are usually normal when no symptoms are present. Skin tests (intradermal tests, scratch tests) and serum antigen-specific IgE assays can identify offending allergens. The presence of eosinophils in nasal secretions, and nasal challenge testing between episodes when symptoms are absent, is also important in determining the cause. Related disorders include vasomotor rhinitis, characterized by no identifiable allergen and no eosinophils in the nasal mucosa, and eosinophilic rhinitis, characterized by large numbers of eosinophils in the nasal mucosa. Sneezing, watery nasal discharge and nasal obstruction are common in both disorders. Treatment includes effective patient communication, elimination or avoidance of the triggering allergen, pharmacotherapy, desensitization therapy and sometimes surgery. Treatment options (Table 1.2) will vary in each patient depending on clinical presentation and severity of symptoms. Acute sinusitis often develops after a common cold with extension of acute inflammation from the nasal passages to the sinus mucosa. There is continuity between the nasal cavity and sinuses, so infection can readily spread. The major causative organisms in both children and adults are H. influenzae, Pneumococcus and M. catarrhalis. The maxillary sinuses, followed by the frontal sinuses, are most often involved. Symptoms of acute sinusitis overlap those of the common cold but also differ depending on which sinuses are affected. Patients may complain of cheek pain (maxillary sinusitis), pain around the eyes and base of the nose (ethmoid sinusitis), or frontal headache (frontal sinusitis). In addition, purulent nasal discharge, nasal obstruction and altered sense of smell can occur. The medical history should inquire about cold-like symptoms and other symptoms mentioned above. A description of the nasal discharge is important. Examination of the nasal cavity usually reveals redness and swelling of the mucosa, with purulent drainage in the middle meatus. The site of drainage will vary depending on the affected sinus. Sinus X-ray and CT show clouding or air–fluid levels in the affected sinus. When the maxillary sinus is involved, the presence of secretions on maxillary puncture through the inferior meatus will confirm a diagnosis of maxillary sinusitis. Secretions from the middle meatus should be obtained for microbiological tests. Treatment of acute sinusitis is conservative in the absence of complications. Symptomatic treatment of cold-like symptoms, antibiotics, anti-inflammatory/analgesic drugs and anti-inflammatory enzymes can be prescribed. Topical administration of a nasal vasoconstrictor will reduce mucosal swelling and improve drainage of secretions. Sinus irrigation, for example, puncture and lavage of the maxillary sinuses, is helpful in some cases. If there is a dental cause, patients should be referred for complete dental evaluation. Chronic airway disease is a general term for airway dysfunction ranging from the trachea to the bronchi and bronchioles in the lower respiratory tract. The major disorders are collectively known as COPD, including emphysema, chronic bronchitis, bronchiectasis and diffuse panbronchiolitis. However, other chronic lung parenchymal and airway diseases associated with recurrent lower respiratory infections, including old tuberculosis, non-tuberculous mycobacterial infections, pneumoconiosis, pulmonary fibrosis and chronic asthma, are also in this category. There is no uniform definition for acute exacerbation of chronic airway disease, but an internationally accepted definition for acute exacerbation of COPD18 is the development of any or all of the following three major symptoms: increased dyspnoea, increased sputum purulence and increased sputum volume. If only one of these major symptoms is present, at least one of five of the following must also be present: (i) upper respiratory infection within 5 days; (ii) fever not due to another cause; (iii) increased wheezing; (iv) increased cough; or (v) at least a 20% increase in respiratory rate or pulse. In addition, each of the following must be excluded: heart failure, pulmonary embolism, pneumonia, pneumothorax, pleural effusion and arrhythmia. The most common causes of acute exacerbation of COPD are thought to be airway infections and air pollution, but in one-third of severe exacerbations, the cause cannot be identified.19 In cases of acute exacerbations due to an infection, the causative organism varies depending on underlying lung disease and other patient factors.20 In relatively young patients with an FEV1≥50%, H. influenzae, Pneumococcus and M. catarrhalis are common, often preceded by a viral infection. In older patients with an FEV1 < 50%; in patients with an FEV1 of 50–65% but also serious underling disease (e.g. diabetes mellitus, congestive heart failure, chronic renal disease, chronic liver disease); and in patients with frequent acute exacerbations four or more times per year; H. influenzae, Pneumococcus and M. catarrhalis also predominate, but drug resistant organisms are also common. In patients with persistent purulent sputum or progressive dyspnoea, in addition to the above organisms, enteric Gram-negative bacteria and P. aeruginosa should also be considered. In acute infectious exacerbations, increased purulent sputum production is one of the main symptoms. Sputum Gram stain and culture are helpful in identifying the causative organism. Treatment with antimicrobials is required for infectious exacerbations, but sputum cultures should ideally be obtained to identify the causative organism. If cultures cannot be obtained or the results will take considerable time, empirical therapy for the likely organisms mentioned above should be started. Drug susceptibility is an important consideration. Other necessary treatment, including bronchodilators, corticosteroids, oxygen and mechanical ventilation (including non-invasive positive pressure ventilation) should be provided.19,21,22 The effectiveness of expectorants in infectious exacerbations has not been established.21,22 Cough is an important defence mechanism in COPD, and regular use of antitussives is discouraged. Respiratory syncytial virus is a common cause of bronchiolitis in young children, and it is the cause of the common cold in 5% of patients of all ages.23 Much remains unknown about the clinical features of RS virus infection in healthy adults, but it is a common cause of the common cold in winter months. Immunity to RS virus is incomplete even in healthy adults, and reinfection can occur throughout life. In older individuals or patients with underlying conditions (e.g. chronic cardiopulmonary disease, malignant tumours, postorgan transplant), life-threatening pneumonia may occur.24 In otherwise healthy adults, upper respiratory infections due to RS virus usually last longer than those due to other viruses, and wheezing, prolonged cough and productive sputum are common.25 In older persons, the incidence of cough is very high with RS virus infection. The diagnosis of RS virus infection in adults is difficult, aggressive evaluation is rarely done, and outbreaks of RS virus coincide with those of influenza virus.26 Therefore, in patients evaluated for a productive cough during the winter, those who are antigen-negative for influenza virus or who fail to respond to anti-influenza treatment may have infection due to RS virus or human metapneumovirus (hMPV) (discussed later). To date there are no effective vaccines for RS virus. In children, the use of mAb to prevent bronchiolitis and effective treatment with ribavirin, an inhaled antiviral agent, has been reported. In adults, however, no effective means of treatment or prevention are available. Human metapneumovirus is a newly discovered paramyxovirus that infects humans.27 hMPV is difficult to culture, and antibody assays are not widely available, so the pattern of infection in Japan is not well known. Like RS virus, infection is most common in childhood, but reinfection may occur throughout life in adults.28 Serious pneumonia can occur in older persons and those with underlying disease. hMPV belongs to the same paramyxovirus family as RS virus, and the clinical features of infection are similar. However, a study comparing clinical manifestations in healthy adults found that the incidence of hoarseness and productive cough were higher with hMPV than with RS virus.29 At present, no effective vaccine or treatment is available for hMPV. Aspiration is the inspiratory sucking of liquids or foods (exogenous) or oropharyngeal secretions or gastric contents (endogenous) into the airway from the larynx through the vocal cords. In healthy adults, choking and violent coughing sometimes occurs, but the cough reflex in this case is a physiological reaction. Pathological aspiration is broadly divided into witnessed aspiration, in which a large amount of liquid or food is suddenly inhaled into the airway, and silent aspiration, in which a small amount of secretions or gastric contents is inhaled into the airway without being noticed. The former occurs in patients with decreased consciousness, dysphagia, or after vomiting, and severe pneumonia may occur. The latter is associated with impaired swallowing and cough reflexes and is a cause of aspiration pneumonia. Risk factors for aspiration include being elderly, cerebrovascular injury, Parkinson’s disease, dementia, GER, prolonged bedridden states, alcoholism and use of certain drugs. In patients with repeated coughing who have these risk factors, aspiration must be considered. (Please refer to cough in specific populations: elderly patients.) All prolonged and chronic coughs start out as an acute cough, and many prolonged and chronic coughs are associated with respiratory tract infections. Therefore, when diagnosing and treating acute coughs, physicians must also be familiar with the evaluation of prolonged and chronic coughs. Although rare as compared with young children, patients with decreased consciousness, and elderly patients, accidental inhalation of a foreign body as a cause of acute cough is sometimes seen in otherwise healthy adults. Bronchoscopy or surgery may be indicated in these patients.

papers.title: Treatment of Otitis Media with Effusion
papers.abstract: 청력 감소는 삼출성 중이염(Otitis Media with Effusion： OME)의 가장 빈번한 합병증이면서 병적인 결 과(morbid outcome)이다. 이러한 청력 감소의 정도는 삼출액의 생리적 성상들보다는 삼출액의 용량에 의해 결 정되고, 삼출성 중이염은 20 dB 이상의 경도에서 중등 도 전음성 난청을 동반하는 경우가 많다.1) 삼출성 중이 염의 진단 방법으로 쓰이는 청력 검사는 유소아 연령에 서 시행하는 데에는 제한이 있으나, 중이내 병변이 청력 에 미치는 효과를 평가하는데 있어서는 도움을 줄 수 있다.2) 언어 발달기에 지속적이거나 간헐적인 전음성 난 청과 소아의 인지적 언어 발달 장애와의 연관성에 대해 서는 이미 잘 알려져 있지만, 이러한 장애들을 야기할 수 있는 청력 감소의 정도와 기간이 정확히 언급된 바 없다.1)3)
papers.venue: Journal of Clinical Otolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery

papers.title: Giftiga växter för hästar på sommarbete
papers.abstract: Vaxter kan innehalla manga olika typer av giftiga substanser vilket kan gora det svart for en veterinar att faststalla diagnos och vilket botemedel som ska anvandas vid forgiftning. En av de vanligast forekommande giftiga substanserna inom vaxtriket ar alkaloider. Idegran, odort och stands innehaller alkaloider som paverkar nervsystem, lever och hjarta. Glykosider ar en annan typ av giftig substans som t. ex kan paverka hjartat och ge skador vid hudkontakt. Fingerborgsblomma ar ett exempel pa en vaxt som innehaller glykosider. Tanniner som exempelvis finns i ek, kan skada tarmslemhinnan, levern och njurarna. Vaxter som innehaller polyyner paverkar bland annat centrala nervsystemet och kan hittas i exempelvis sprangort som orsakat manga forgiftningsfall. I vaxter kan det aven finnas andra giftiga substanser, som t. ex nitrat/nitrit, oxalater, furokumariner, flyktiga oljor och thiaminaser. Symtom pa forgiftning sker ibland fort, inom 15 min, medan hastar i andra fall kan bli exponerade for giftiga substanser under en langre period innan symtom pa forgiftning intrader. Slutsatser fran denna litteraturstudie ar att manga vaxter skapar forgiftning i bade torrt och farskt tillstand, samt att en del vaxter behover konsumeras i storre mangd an andra for att forgiftning ska uppsta. Darfor ar det viktigt att hastagare inspekterar sina hagar och inventerar vaxter som finns dar samt lar sig vilka som ar farliga, sa att forgiftning sa langt som mojligt kan undvikas.

papers.title: [Development of occupational asthma. Follow-up R.F.E. of 23 cases].
papers.abstract: Occupational asthma can either improve or develop into chronic respiratory insufficiency. It is often difficult to predict which course will be followed. Here we report the follow-up of respiratory function of 23 patients with occupational asthma of at least one year's standing, due to various substances; several prognostic factors are discussed.

papers.title: Hereditary acrokeratotic poikiloderma
papers.abstract: A dominantly inherited disorder has affected ten members of a family group. At present we recognize the following categories of clinical involvement: (1) vesicopustule formation which remains confined to the hands and feet (this process commences at from 1 to 3 months of age and resolves in late childhood); (2) widespread eczematous dermatitis somewhat resembling atopic eczema which starts between the ages of 3 and 6 months and completely resolves by 5 years of age; (3) the gradual appearance of a diffuse poikiloderma with striate and reticulate atrophy which spares only the face, scalp, and ears (the poikiloderma persists into adult life); and (4) the development of keratotic papules on the hands, feet, elbows, and knees, which first appear at varying times prior to 5 years of age and persist indefinitely.

papers.title: ３．疾患別・危険な症状とサイン
papers.abstract: 頭蓋内病変と診断された場合，その時点で頭蓋内圧亢進症状が認められなくても，つねにその状態になる可能性があります．　頭蓋内圧亢進に対して，看護に求められることは2 点です．1 つ目は，頭蓋内圧亢進の進行を想定して症状の有無を観察し，頭蓋内圧亢進を早期に発見し脳ヘルニアなどの重篤な状態となるのを防ぐことです．2 つ目は，患者の頭痛や嘔吐などの苦痛の緩和に努めるとともに，頭蓋内圧亢進を増強させる動作を避けることです．

papers.title: Occupational lung disease
papers.abstract: Some occupational lung diseases are defined by their clinical or pathological nature (e.g. occupational asthma or mesothelioma), while others are defined by their specific etiology (e.g. silicosis, farmer’s lung). Most fall into one of three categories. The first is airways disease, including occupational asthma (induced by a workplace agent), work-exacerbated asthma (preexisting asthma provoked by one or more agents at work), and irritant-induced asthma (initiated by a single, toxic exposure to a respiratory irritant); COPD and obliterative bronchiolitis may arise from workplace exposures, and around 10% of lung cancers have an occupational etiology. The second is parenchymal diseases, incorporating the many types of pneumoconiosis, differentiated by the dust that caused them, and the many types of extrinsic allergic alveolitis (or hypersensitivity pneumonia) categorized by the occupations in which they arise. The third is pleural diseases comprising pleural plaques, diffuse pleural thickening, and mesothelioma.

papers.title: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) — clinical symptoms
papers.abstract: The initial symptoms of RA can involve the joints alone or be more systemic. Joint symptoms include pain of various intensities with more intense pain occurring in the morning. Another prominent symptom is morning stiffness, usually lasting more than one hour, which distinguishes the pain from that occurring in osteoarthrosis. Systemic symptoms include general malaise, tiredness, fatigue, subfebrile temperatures, weight loss and sleep disturbance. Metacarpophalangeal (MCP), proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints and wrist (RC) are the most frequently affected in early RA.

papers.title: Predicción mediante productos de distorsión de hipoacusia en trabajadores expuestos al ruido en el Hospital General Universitario Gregorio Marañon
papers.abstract: La Hipoacusia inducida por ruido se define como la disminucion de la capacidad auditiva de uno o ambos oidos, parcial o total, permanente y acumulativa, de tipo neurosensorial que se origina gradualmente, durante y como resultado de la exposicion a niveles perjudiciales de ruido en el ambiente laboral, de tipo continuo o intermitente de intensidad relativamente alta (> 85 dB) durante un periodo prolongado de tiempo.En Espana el ruido es el contaminante ambiental mas frecuente encontrado en el conjunto de todos los sectores de la actividad, segun las estadisticas de enfermedades profesionales declaras ante el ministerio de trabajo en los ultimos 10 anos, ocupa el tercer lugar de frecuencia despues de la tendinopatias por sobre uso y neuropatias perifericassecundarias presion (10).En la actualidad el diagnostico y seguimiento de los trabajadores expuesto al ruido se realiza con la audiometria, considerada como Prueba Gold estandar (19), a pesar de esto presenta desventajas importantes como son, la subjetividad en el momento de realizar la prueba, depender en gran parte de la respuesta dada por el paciente, al igual que de la calidad del equipo. Siendo muy util para el diagnostico de la hipoacusia(instaurada), el paciente que presente perdida auditiva diagnosticada a traves de este metodo, en el caso de la hipoacusia por ruido, no seran reversibles...

papers.title: Continuous and long-term infusion of lidocaine is effective for morphine-ineffective, intractable cough induced by voluntary movement: A case report
papers.abstract: 持続する咳嗽は時に日常生活の大きな支障となり, 咳嗽の症状緩和は終末期においても重要な課題である. 今回, リドカインの持続静注が, モルヒネなどの薬剤が奏効せず体動時に頻発・持続する難治性乾性咳嗽に対し, 1年以上の長期にわたり有効であった症例について報告する. 症例は50歳代, 女性. 乳がん肺転移. 腫瘍が気管支内に浸潤しており, 腫瘍の機械的刺激が原因と思われる咳嗽の訴えがあった. 症状は体動に伴って出現することが多く, 咳嗽による苦痛が患者の生活の質を著しく低下させていた. 上記症状に対し塩酸モルヒネの持続静注を480mg/日まで行うも奏効せず, リドカインの持続静注を480mg/日から開始した. 開始後同日より症状の改善を認め, 更に960mg/日まで増量した後, 1年以上症状は安定したまま経過した. またリドカイン中毒などの副作用も出現しなかった. Palliat Care Res 2008;3(1):305-307

papers.title: Avaliação da qualidade de vida e fatores associados à satisfação dos pacientes submetidos ao tratamento cirúrgico da Doença do Refluxo Gastroesofágico
papers.abstract: Epígrafe"The symptoms are quite complex and can go from a feeling of heartburn that disturbs the digestion, to symptoms related to the heart, to the lungs or both, to the difficulty in taking long breaths, to occasional vomiting, to vomiting occurring after every meal, or only after taking certain kinds of food, or taking either hot or cold drinks, to difficulty in swallowing, and to many other disturbs that might arise on account of a special hernia and of the temperament, habits, profession, emotion, age, sex of the patient"

papers.title: Connective Tissue Diseases
papers.abstract: Obstructive sleep apnea is defined as periodic cessation of airflow (duration ≥10 seconds) during sleep with complete obstruction of the upper airway and continued respiratory effort. Typically, the episode is terminated by a temporary arousal from sleep and return of normal upper airway patency. Hypopnea is defined as partial obstruction of the upper airway during sleep (duration ≥10 seconds), usually with a resultant desaturation of at least 4%. Hypopnea is also typically terminated by a temporary arousal. Such periodic episodes of apnea and hypopnea usually result in fragmented sleep and periodic desaturations.

papers.title: Endolymphatic Hydrops (Meniere’s Syndrome)
papers.abstract: The clinical profile of Meniere’s disease evolved over the years from a nonspecific description of just about any combination of hearing loss and vertigo to a characteristic clinical triad of fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo. Once a characteristic pathology—endolymphatic hydrops—was discovered in the late 1930s,3,4 the next question was whether patients with the typical clinical profile consistently showed this pathology. As more and more pathological specimens have been reported, the answer to this question is, usually but not always.5–8 Complicating matters further, endolymphatic hydrops can be found in ears from patients without the typical symptoms of Meniere’s disease and, occasionally, even in patients without ear symptoms.8–10 Furthermore, it has become apparent that Meniere’s syndrome and the characteristic inner ear pathology can be produced by several different etiologies, including infections (syphilitic, bacterial, and viral) and after traumatic and metabolic injuries to the inner ear.

papers.title: Ein seltener Fall der chronischen Tracheobronchomegalie als Zufallsbefund bei COPD
papers.abstract: Eine wichtige primäre Ursache der Tracheomegalie ist das Mounier-Kuhn-Syndrom. Das Mounier-Kuhn-Syndrom ist eine seltene, chronische Tracheomegalie, die durch eine pathologische Erweiterung des Tracheadiameters bis zu 3,0 cm gekennzeichnet ist. Zusätzlich sind eine Erweiterung des rechten Hauptbronchus über 2,0 cm und des linken Hauptbronchus über 1,8 cm zu beobachten. Die genaue Ursache dieser Erkrankung ist noch nicht vollständig geklärt, jedoch werden primär-genetische und sekundäre Aspekte diskutiert, einschließlich möglicher Verbindungen zu anderen Erkrankungen wie dem Ehlers-Danlos-Syndrom, Cutis laxa oder dem Marfan-Syndrom (Chandran et al. BMJ Case Rep 2021; 14 (01): e239876).
papers.venue: RöFo - Fortschritte auf dem Gebiet der Röntgenstrahlen und der bildgebenden Verfahren

papers.title: Clinical Manifestations of Native Valve Endocarditis
papers.abstract: Although all types of infective endocarditis (IE) share a common pathogenesis, nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) (Chapter 5), there are marked differences in their manifestations. Nowhere is this difference as striking than that between subacute and acute (IE) of native valves. The former disease is an indolent process that is marked by fever, fatigue, and anorexia. It is a wasting disease that may go on for longer than a one year if untreated. Acute IE follows an extremely aggressive course with intractable heart failure leading to death in a few days (1,2).

papers.title: 건강칼럼 - 특이한 현대병 '공황장애'
papers.abstract: 정신계통의 특이한 현대병 '공황장애'는 갑자기 가슴이 조여들고 숨이 막히면서 손발이 저리고 어지러워져 곧 쓰러질 것 같은 느낌이 20~30분간 계속되며 이 증상이 주기적으로 나타나는 정신계통의 질환이다. 정신과 질환임에도 불구하고 여러 가지 급성 신체증상들을 동반해 심장질환 등 내과 계통의 질환으로 오진하기 쉬운 질병이다. 대개의 경우 약물치료후 2~3개월이면 호전되고 1년반 정도 장기 약물복용이 필요하다.

papers.title: Ból fantomowy - wyzwanie terapeutyczne
papers.abstract:
Po amputacji konczyny lub jej cześci mogą wystąpic iluzoryczne doznania czuciowe, ze konczyna jest nadal
obecna. Takie objawy nazywamy czuciem fantomowym. Bezpośrednio po amputacji dolegliwości o takim
charakterze wystepują u wiekszości chorych (do 97% przypadkow). W miare uplywu czasu wrazenia czuciowe
i bol zanikają, a u wiekszości chorych pojawia sie wrazenie, ze amputowana konczyna zmniejsza sie i na
wzor teleskopu przybliza do kikuta. Po 2 latach od amputacji i po calkowitym zagojeniu rany przewlekly
i zazwyczaj oporny na leczenie bol wystepuje juz tylko u 2-4% chorych. Taki rodzaj bolu określamy mianem
bolu fantomowego. Zarowno czucie fantomowe, jak i bol fantomowy mogą wystąpic rowniez po chirurgicznym
odcieciu innych cześci ciala, na przyklad po amputacji piersi. U niektorych chorych bol fantomowy moze
ustąpic nawet po kilku latach, ale dosyc czesto powraca ponownie. Jego natezenie jest bardzo zroznicowane
- od ledwie zauwazalnego do bardzo uciązliwego, prowadzącego do ograniczenia aktywności zyciowej
chorego. Leczenie takiego bolu jest sporym wyzwaniem terapeutycznym nie tylko dla lekarza, ale takze dla
calego zespolu prowadzącego kompleksową terapie (fizjoterapeuty, psychologa). Znajomośc patomechanizmow
powstawania bolu fantomowego, zrozumienie podstaw i konieczności wieloczynnikowej terapii umozliwia
optymalne leczenie pacjenta cierpiącego z powodu tego rodzaju bolu.
 Medycyna Paliatywna w Praktyce 2010; 4, 2: 66-73

papers.title: [When pneumonia does not respond to antibiotic therapy].
papers.abstract: The favorable pneumonia outcome with antibiotics according to the recommendations is defined by improving clinical symptoms in 48-72 hours followed by their normalization within less than 10 days. This is different to stop progression of radiological abnormalities that can be delayed for 48-72 hours and moreover to radiological normalization which may require 4 to 8 weeks. The non favorable outcome, 48-72 hours after a first line of antibiotic therapy results in the vast majority of cases, from an infection: the pneumonia is not or poorly treated. The non favorable outcome 5-6 days after two successive lines of antibiotic therapy may also result from a non infectious cause: immunologic, toxic or tumoral pneumonitis. Practitioner dilemna is not to worry too early (slow-resolving pneumonia with clinical cure in normal time but slow radiological resolution) or too late (non-resolving pneumonia with no clinical cure and persistence or radiological extension).

papers.title: Chronic Kidney Disease Begins Slowly and Lasts a Long Time
papers.abstract: Chronic kidney disease is increasingly becoming a major public health problem. It is characterized by a disorder in the structure and function of the kidneys that lasts longer than 3 months. It is a condition in which there is a slow decrease in kidney function. The problem with this disease is that the signs and symptoms are often nonspecific as they can be caused by other diseases.
papers.venue: Advancements in Journal of Urology and Nephrology

papers.title: Locally advanced disease and advanced disease
papers.abstract: Abstract This somewhat alarming term is used to describe a prostate cancer which, although it has spread to the tis, sues immediately outside the prostate gland itself, has not given rise to detectable disease elsewhere, such as in lymph glands or bones. It is a more serious situation than disease confined to the prostate gland, for a number of reasons: would, untreated, cause problems to the patient (see Chapter 3). Hence, it is more likely to need treatment, although this is not always the case (for example, a slowly progressing tumour in an elderly patient with other significant illnesses might never cause problems within that patient’s lifetime).

papers.title: 失眠的评价
papers.abstract: 失眠的定义失眠分为急性和慢性失眠.急性失眠通常持续时间不超过2 w,与应激状态有关,例如上班、搬家、婚姻或亲人朋友的去世等.而慢性失眠则是失眠持续超过3 w以上,或者不充足睡眠伴随着日间睡意和抑郁,且持续时间不少于1个月。

papers.title: 呼吸道“杀手”——慢性阻塞性肺疾病
papers.abstract: 您或您身边的人是否被以下情况或症状所困扰？40岁以上;有吸烟史;目前或曾经接触职业粉尘和化学物质;日常工作或生活的环境存在空气污染;与同龄人相比,活动时更容易感觉气短或呼吸困难;与同龄人相比,容易出现喘息（呼吸急促）和胸闷;出现体重下降、食欲减退、情绪低落、焦虑等全身性症状;家族中有亲属患有慢性阻塞性肺疾病.以上为慢性阻塞性肺疾病的主要表现及危险因素,若您存在以上症状或情况中的3条或3条以上,应及时向医生咨询,以明确是否患有慢性阻塞性肺疾病.

papers.title: Common Diseases of the Vulva
papers.abstract: All females, regardless of age, are vulnerable to vulvar irritation and disease.Sometimes the irritation is short lived and may not cause the individual to seektreatment. Symptoms can be mild to severe, intermittent to constant, and predict-able or unpredictable. Typically, a woman decides to see a health-care providerwhen she has begun to experience a disruption in her daily activities, which, mostlikely, has begun to affect her sexual life as well as her self-esteem (1-4).

papers.title: "Very late" relapses in Hodgkin's disease patients: a rare but real phenomenon.
papers.abstract: In the past several decades, scientific and therapeutic advances have transformed Hodgkin's disease from a uniformly fatal illness to one that can be treated with the expectation of long-term remission or cure in the majority of cases. Because patients now survive for long periods after treatment, various late complications are being identified. Among patients with such late complications, some have been reported to experience "very late" relapses (> 10 years). Here we document recurrences in three patients with Hodgkin's disease more than 10 years after remission.

papers.title: Psychological aspects due to chronic pain
papers.abstract: Chronic pain is a persistent pain which continues to afflict a patient despite treatment of the causes which originated that pain and which interferes in the normal everyday family and working life of that patient, developing at times into his/her only problem and conditioning his/her life and that of his/her family and acquaintances. Chronic pain is a worldwide disorder and it affects 23.4% of the population in Spain.

papers.title: Hereditary Acrokeratotic Poikiloderma
papers.abstract: A dominantly inherited disorder has affected ten members of a family group. At present we recognize the following categories of clinical involvement: (1) vesicopustule formation which remains confined to the hands and feet (this process commences at from 1 to 3 months of age and resolves in late childhood); (2) widespread eczematous dermatitis somewhat resembling atopic eczema which starts between the ages of 3 and 6 months and completely resolves by 5 years of age; (3) the gradual appearance of a diffuse poikiloderma with striate and reticulate atrophy which spares only the face, scalp, and ears (the poikiloderma persists into adult life); and (4) the development of keratotic papules on the hands, feet, elbows, and knees, which first appear at varying times prior to 5 years of age and persist indefinitely.

papers.title: Why are the diagnosis and management of orofacial pain so challenging?
papers.abstract: Pain is the primary reason patients visit a physician or dentist, and the diagnosis and management of pain in the face, mouth and jaws have been integral components of dental practice since dentistry became a widely recognized profession in the 19th century. Epidemiologic studies reveal that a large proportion of the population in many countries currently suffers from temporomandibular disorders (TMD), toothaches, headaches and other conditions associated with orofacial pain.1,2 Indeed, some of the most common pain conditions in the body occur in the orofacial region and many of these are chronic (i.e., lasting more than 3 months). These chronic conditions range from such common problems as TMD and burning mouth to less-frequent disorders, such as trigeminal neuralgia and so-called atypical odontalgia. Most chronic pains represent a diagnostic or management challenge to dentists for several reasons, including the inadequate education most dentists receive regarding pain.

papers.title: 中医辨治慢性咳嗽的体会
papers.abstract: 咳嗽为呼吸系统疾病的常见症状,临床上将咳嗽时间≥8周,X线胸片无明显异常,以咳嗽为主或为惟一症状者,称为不明原因慢性咳嗽(简称慢性咳嗽)[1],属中医内伤咳嗽范畴,其症多为干咳,喉痒或咽痛,遇风寒或刺激性气味加剧,咳嗽平卧为甚,重者咳而遗溺,X线胸片无明显异常.该病迁延难愈,治疗不当,可延数月或数年。

papers.title: 慢性骨盆疼痛综合征（CPPS）疼痛的发病机制研究进展
papers.abstract: 一、CPPS的定义和疼痛特点 慢性骨盆疼痛综合征（CPPS）为Ⅲ型慢性前列腺炎，出现持续或反复发作性盆腔疼痛，且至少持续或反复发作6个月，常伴有消极的认知、行为、性行为和情感后果，与下尿路病变、性功能障碍、肠功能紊乱或妇科疾病相关，缺乏感染或其他明显的病原学证据[1]。

papers.title: Über den Gewebsturgor
papers.abstract: Mißt man mit dosierbarem Druck die Eindrückbarkeit der Haut am Daumen, so sicht man unter Kontrolle des Fingerabdruckes den Druckring nach 3–10 Min. verschwinden. Dieser Zeitraum gilt für Gesunde und Kranke, sofern diese unter 50 Jahre sind. Der Zeitraum ist kürzer bei Kindern und Halberwachsenen (1/2–2 Min.). Bei älteren Leuten, die zugleich schwerere Erkrankungen innerer Organe, speziell Kreislauferkrankungen haben, hält sich der Druckring oft mehrere Stunden (1/1–21/2) oder 3 Stunden). Trotz aller Einwände, die man gegen die Methode und ihre Ergebnisse machen kann, darf man aus dieser Tatsache schließen, daß der Turgor der Haut mehr abhängig ist vom Alter als von schweren chronischen Erkrankungen der inneren Organe einschließlich der Kreislauforgane und der Nieren.
papers.venue: Zeitschrift für die Gesamte Experimentelle Medizin

papers.title: 老让肺脏“背黑锅”的慢性咳嗽
papers.abstract: 咳嗽是人体的一种重要的防御和生理反射机制，但剧烈的长期咳嗽会影响患者的呼吸、心脏和日常工作、生活。当患者咳嗽时间大于三周，经胸部影像学（胸片或CT）检查表现正常，并且不吸烟（或停止吸烟4周），咯痰较少，血象无明显异常等感染迹象，也没有因高血压而服用血管紧张素转化酶抑制剂，就可以被诊断为慢性咳嗽。

papers.title: Internet-Based Vestibular Rehabilitation for Patients with Chronic Vestibular Syndrome
papers.abstract: Dizziness and vertigo are common symptoms that can last for months or years (i.e., chronic vestibular syndrome). Vestibular rehabilitation can help

papers.title: Chronic pulmonary complications due to toxic epidermal necrolysis
papers.abstract:
Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) is the most severe form of skin reactions caused by drugs or infection. Acute pulmonary complications
in TEN are often observed. The mortality is especially high in those who suffer chronic pulmonary complications of TEN such as
bronchiolitis obliterance, which occur as a consequence of bronchial epithelial injury. We report a case of a 16-year-old male who had
required mechanical ventilation due to acute respiratory distress syndrome caused by TEN at 8 years of age. Although the patient initially
recovered from acute respiratory distress syndrome, he required mechanical ventilation again due to severe chronic pulmonary
complications of bronchiolitis obliterance and bronchiectasis caused by respiratory epithelial detachment. Thereafter, chronic bronchitis
and chronic sinusitis has persisted due to mucosal ciliary dysfunction and several episodes of spontaneous pneumothorax has
occurred. However, despite these persisting and serious sequelae of TEN, the patient has survived for 8 years. We report a rare case of
a patient with long-term chronic pulmonary complications who had previously suffered TEN 8 years ago.

papers.title: Alcohol: A friend or foe of IBD
papers.abstract: Ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn's disease are both characterized by periods of clinical quiescence interrupted by clinical relapses featuring escalating inflammation in the colon or the full leng...

papers.title: Alergie w wieku starszym Allergy in the elderly
papers.abstract: Streszczenie Choroby alergiczne wystepują rzadziej u osob starszych niz u osob ponizej 65 r.z., powinny jednak byc uwzgledniane w diagnostyce roznicowej, gdyz prawidlowe rozpoznanie i leczenie moze wplynąc na poprawe jakości zycia chorych w starszym wieku. Zmiany w ukladzie immunologicznym, związane z procesem starzenia organizmu, określane jako ,,immunosenescence”, nie manifestują sie zmniejszeniem czestości chorob alergicznych i astmy. Ponadto oslabienie bariery naskorkowej i nablonkowej, ulatwia wnikanie alergenom, a stwierdzana przewaga limfocytow Th2 nad Th1, u cześci pacjentow moze prowadzic do zapoczątkowania lub nasilenia istniejącej alergii. Diagnostyka i leczenie chorob alergicznych i astmy nie rozni sie znacząco od postepowania u mlodszych chorych, jednakze moze byc utrudniona z uwagi na przyjmowanie wielu lekow i choroby wspolistniejące. W pracy omowiono czestośc wystepowania chorob alergicznych oraz odrebności postepowania u pacjentow w starszym wieku. Slowa kluczowe: alergia, choroby alergiczne, wiek podeszly Summary Despite the fact that allergic diseases are less common in the elderly than in patients under 65 years old, allergy should be consider in the differential diagnosis of diseases in geriatric patients, because proper diagnosis and treatment can improve the quality of life of elderly patients. Changes in the immune system, associated with the ageing of the organism known as immunosenescence do not manifest a decrease in the incidence of allergic diseases and asthma. In addition, the weakening of the epidermal and epithelial barrier, facilitates the penetration of allergens, and the immune deviation towards Th2 predominance, may lead to the onset or worsening of existing allergies. Diagnosis and treatment of allergic diseases and asthma is not significantly different from the procedure in younger patients, however, may be more difficult in elderly patients due to polytherapy and comorbidities. This paper discuss the prevalence and management of allergic diseases in the elderly patients.

papers.title: Maladie de Leo-Buerger faisant suite à une intoxication au cannabis
papers.abstract: La maladie de Léo-Buerger est une artérite du sujet jeune généralement de sexe masculin et classiquement associée au tabac. Sa pathogénie exacte demeure inconnue mais parait-il que le tabac nest pas le seul facteur toujours incriminé dans sa genèse. Le cannabis est une drogue cultivée en zone équatoriale dont lassociation avec la maladie de Léo-Buerger a été décrite la première fois par Sterne en 1960. On en connaît plusieurs sous-types, dont le chanvre indien qui en plus de son effet stupéfiant, sécrète une substance riche en cannabinoïdes dont le D9 tétrahydrocannabitol qui détermine une vasoconstriction périphérique par effet tyramine-like sur les terminaisons nerveuses adrénergiques. La maladie de Léo-Buerger associée au cannabis se caractériserait par un début plus précoce (28 ans), une présentation clinique à type de thromboangéite oblitérante, des lésions très distales, une atteinte fréquente des membres supérieurs et une intoxication tabagique moindre. Il nexiste actuellement pas de traitement spécifique, cependant, le sevrage et les soins locaux sont fondamentaux. Liloprost intra-veineux peut aider à passer un cap difficile et apporter un bénéfice en termes de diminution des taux damputation, mais les problèmes de tolérance et de coût limitent son utilisation. Le recours à dautres traitements comme les vasodilatateurs classiques, les anti-agrégants plaquettaires, les anti-coagulants, la thrombolyse in situ, les solutés cristalloïdes et colloïdes et la revascularisation chirurgicale ont été utilisés sans grand succès et lamputation reste indispensable lorsque lischémique est irréversible. Nous rapportons le cas dun jeune homme de 31 ans, non tabagique et consommant en moyenne six joints par semaine de cannabis. Lexamen clinique objectivait des claudications intermittentes, une ischémie aiguë distale des membres inférieurs avec abolition des pouls distaux, nécroses et gangrènes plus marquées au niveau du gros orteil droit et du troisième orteil gauche. Le reste de lexamen somatique était normal et il ny avait pas de phénomène de Raynaud, ni dischémie distale des membres supérieurs, ni de symptomatologie articulaire associée. Un bilan à la recherche dautres facteurs de risques cardio-vasculaires, le dosage des facteurs de coagulation et les examens immunologiques à la recherche dune vascularite étaient normaux. Limagerie vasculaire montrait une occlusion des artères pédieuse et tibiale postérieure avec présence de collatérales plantaires en «tire-bouchon». Le traitement consistait à des cures courtes dIlosprost cinq jours de suite en milieu hospitalier à une dose de 1,5ng/kg/min et des soins locaux associant des nettoyages, une excision des tissus superficiels nécrosés et des pansements gras, permettant une cicatrisation en quatre mois. Par ailleurs, le sevrage était obtenu graduellement dans un centre spécialisé.

papers.title: Prevalencia de bruxismo en estudiantes de la facultad de odontología de la Universidad Veracruzana
papers.abstract: El bruxismo o rechinar de dientes es una patologia de etiologia no bien definida, corresponde a un trastorno del movimiento en el sistema masticatorio, caracterizado entre otras cosas por el apriete y rechinamiento dentario durante el sueno aunque en ocasiones el paciente estando despierto, puede efectuar el rechinamiento dental. Este habito frecuentemente puede darse de manera inconsciente, aunque la mayoria de las personas en algun momento de su vida llegan a rechinar los dientes, en otros se convierte mas que en un habito en una patologia, pues desencadena graves trastornos del aparato estomatognatico a largo plazo si no se trata a tiempo. La importancia de su estudio radica en que se le considera un factor etiologico en las alteraciones funcionales y dolorosas de la unidad craneocervicomandibular (2), no esta perfectamente determinada la influencia de una situacion estresante en su aparicion y desarrollo, sin embargo, existen caracteristicas que pueden relacionarse con su presencia (3) Palabras claves : bruxismo, rechinar de dientes, salud bucal, salud mental, estres academico, desgastes oclusales.
papers.venue: REVISTA MEXICANA DE MEDICINA FORENSE Y CIENCIAS DE LA SALUD

papers.title: Trekking and high altitude illness
papers.abstract: Jeder zweite Trecker oder Bergsteiger, der rasch (> 300 m/Tag) auf Höhen über 4000 m steigt, hat nach 6 bis 12 Stunden Symptome der Höhenkrankheit. Wir unterscheiden zwei Formen der Höhenkrankheit: die akute Bergkrankheit und das Höhenlungenödem. Die milde und benigne Form der akuten Bergkrankheit äußert sich mit Kopfschmerzen, Appetitlosigkeit, Übelkeit, seltener mit Erbrechen, Schwindelgefühl und Schlaflosigkeit. Die schwere und maligne Form der akuten Bergkrankheit wird Höhenhirnödem genannt und präsentiert sich mit den Symptomen der milden akuten Bergkrankheit mit einer zusätzlichen Gangataxie bis zur Stehunfähigkeit und/oder einer Beeinträchtigung des Bewusstseins bis zum Koma. Die Ursache der akuten Bergkrankheit ist eine zerebrale Dysfunktion, die pathophysiologischen Mechanismen bleiben aber unklar. Das Höhenlungenödem gehört zur Höhenkrankheit, unterscheidet sich aber pathophysiologisch von der akuten Bergkrankheit. Das Höhenlungenödem präsentiert sich klinisch mit stark eingeschränkter Leistungsfähigkeit und Müdigkeit, retrosternalem Druckgefühl, Atemnot, Orthopnoe, Husten, Rasseln in den Atemwegen und blutig tingiertem Auswurf. Pathognomonisch für das Höhenlungen-ödem ist eine Hypoxie-induzierte schwere pulmonal-arterielle Hypertonie. Zweidrittel der Patienten mit Höhenlungenödem hat wegen der schweren Hypoxämie Symptome der malignen akuten Bergkrankheit. Die Behandlung der Höhenkrankheit besteht primär in der Beseitigung der Hypoxie. Acetazolamid (Diamox®), ein Karboanhydrasehemmer, stimuliert die Ventilation und eliminiert die für die Höhe charakteristische periodische Atmung, es eignet sich gut für die Prophylaxe und Behandlung der benignen akuten Bergkrankheit. Die schwere akute Bergkrankheit wird mit Dexamethason (Decadron®) behandelt. Nifedipin (Adalat®), ein wirksamer pulmonaler Vasodilatator, ist das Medikament erster Wahl zur Prophylaxe und Behandlung des Höhenlungenödems.

papers.title: PRESBIKUSIS : Masalah Telinga pada Usia Tua
papers.abstract: Increasing age causes disorders in various organs due to degenerative processes. Presbycusis is one type of disorder that is most often experienced by the elderly group in the field of ENT. This hearing loss is bilateral progressive, irreversible and symmetrical neurosensory caused by cochlear degeneration. This condition cannot be cured, but several actions can be taken to improve the sufferer's quality of life, such as using hearing aids and cochlear implants.

papers.title: PENDEKATAN KLINIK BATUK KRONIK DAN ATAU BERULANG PADA ANAK: Pidato Pcngukuban diucapkan pada peresmian penerimaan jabatan Guru Besar dalam mata pelajaran Ilmu Kesehatan Anak pada Fakultas Kedokteran Universitas Airlangga di Surabaya pada hari Sabtu, tanggal2 Maret 1991
papers.abstract:
Batuk adalah reflek yang normal dan sangat penting untuk mempertahankan higiene saluran pernafasan, tetapi apabila berlebihan merupakan tanda adanya kelainan pada saluran pernafasan, terutama apabila berlangsung lama atau berulang.
Batuk merupakan gejala umum dari penyakit saluran pernafasan bawah yang kronik atau berulang, tetapi batuk-batuk lama dapat juga dijumpai pada keadaan tanpa kelainan paru seperti pada batuk psikogen dan post nasal drip. Batasan batuk kronik dan batuk berulang masih banyak beda pendapat. Sebenarnya etiologi batuk kronik tidak sama dengan etiologi batuk berulang. Batuk berulang seringkali disebabkan oleh infeksi virus berulang-ulang atau asma, sedangkan batuk kronik hampir selalu disebabkan oleh infeksi paru supuratif, jadi lebih parah. Jadi perlu sekali dibedakan dengan tegas kronik atau berulang. Tetapi di dalam praktek sehari-hari seringkali tidak mungkin membedakan kedua itu.

papers.title: Vomiting
papers.abstract: Vomiting can be the presenting symptom of a variety of disorders, ranging from self-limited diseases to life-threatening diseases. The causes of vomiting vary with age of presentation, and pediatricians should develop the skill to identify serious conditions at the earliest stage based on the age of presentation. Bilious emesis at any age is a sign of intestinal obstruction until proven otherwise and needs immediate attention. Vomiting is not always due to a GI disorder, and pediatricians should look for causes outside the GI tract if no GI disease is identified.

papers.title: CONVULSIONS AND ACUTE INFECTIONS
papers.abstract: THE COMMONEST cause of convulsions in children is a high fever associated with an infectious disease. If there are a half million epileptic persons with convulsions each year, then comparatively, millions of patients with infectious fevers have convulsions. Observation for a quarter of a century has taught me to be optimistic about their outcome. Convulsions may occur at any time during the course of an infectious disease, but usually they take place at the onset when the temperature is highest and when a rash, if present, is most prominent. They occur at any age but are commonest from birth to 2 years of age. Convulsions may be localized and unilateral or generalized with no localization, or a combination of reactions may be present. Objectively, convulsions are similar, no matter what the cause. In the majority of patients but one attack occurs, the reaction being so severe that medical aid is
papers.venue: Archives of Pediatrics and Adolescent Medicine

papers.title: Childhood Interstitial Lung Disease in an Immunocompetent Patient Without Exposure
papers.abstract: Childhood interstitial and diffuse lung disease (chILD) is a heterogeneous group of rare and chronic respiratory disorders with an estimated prevalence of 1.5 cases per million children aged 0-18 years. Various etiologies for chILD include but are not limited to systemic diseases, medications, exposure to tobacco, metabolic disorders, and organ diseases. Presented is the case of an immunocompetent young girl who presented with symptoms of recurrent cough and clubbing and was found to have interstitial lung disease.

papers.title: [Social-hygienic problems of child morbidity and infant mortality in Omsk].
papers.abstract: The morbidity rates in infants in Omsk are higher than those in other areas of the country. In its pattern, respiratory diseases (chronic non-specific lung diseases) head the list, peaking in infants of 2 years of age, which is largely associated with the presence of a large-scale petrochemical integrated works. The infantile mortality changes occurring in the past 15 years are characterized by a downward trend, which is associated with medical organizational measures.

papers.title: Recurrent Rheumatic Fever
papers.abstract: Rheumatic fever is a delayed autoimmune response following group A streptococcal infection, which may progress to carditis and lifelong rheumatic heart disease.Although recurrent rheumatic fever in adults is uncommon and the recurrence rate declines with age and with the interval from the initial episode, we describe a patient who has had two episodes of rheumatic fever, one in childhood and one in adult life.

papers.title: [Halitosis in two children caused by a foreign body in the nose].
papers.abstract: In two boys aged 4.5 and 1.5 years with halitosis a nasal foreign body was found. After removal the foetor disappeared. Little is known about the epidemiology of halitosis in children. Apart from specific odours with certain systemic disorders, local pathology such as chronic sinusitis, upper and lower respiratory tract infections and to a lesser degree gastrointestinal disorders may be the cause of the offensive smell. As in adults, bad breath in children is usually related to poor oral hygiene or disease of the oral cavity. The first-line treatment is proper oral hygiene and if necessary dental sanitization. In resistant cases further evaluation should be aimed at disclosing the causative pathology, in which case in children the possibility of a nasal foreign body should also be considered.

papers.title: A Study on Chronic or Recurrent Respiratory Symptoms
papers.abstract: Respiratory tract symptoms such as cough, wheeze, and strider may occur frequently or persist for long periods in a substantial number of children, others may have persistent or recurring lung infiltrates with or without symptoms. It is important to study on clinical significance of this symptoms for avoiding unnecessary test or treatment. Chronic or Recurrent Respiratory Symptoms are similar to cold(感冒) and cough(咳嗽) in Oriental Medicine. Diagnostic criteria is followed : in case of children less than three years old, upper respiratory infections are more than seven per year or lower respiratory infections are more than three ; in case of children three to five years old, upper respiratory infections are more than six per year or lower respiratory infections are more than two ; in case of children six to twelve years old, upper respiratory infections are more than five per year or lower respiratory infections are more than two. In oriental medical treatment is classified into the treatment of internal use, external use, internal and external use, acupuncture, cupping therapy, and combination treatment of chinese and western medicine.
papers.venue: The Journal of Pediatrics of Korean Medicine

papers.title: Evaluation and Treatment of Patients With Constipation
papers.abstract: Constipation occurs in approximately 12% to 19% of the population1 and increases with age, especially after 60 years. Constipation is a common problem in outpatient practices and a frequent reason for admission to the hospital2 and thus is associated with significant adverse effects on quality of life and health care expenditures. Chronic constipation is defined as presence for more than 3 to 6 months of 2 or more of the following symptoms: decreased stool frequency, straining, hard stools, sensation of incomplete emptying or anorectal blockage, requirement for manual maneuvers to pass stool, and rare loose stools in the absence of laxative use.3 Unlike chronic constipation, constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome (IBS-C) presents as recurrent abdominal pain or discomfort associated with hard or infrequent stools or relieved by defecation. There are 3 categories of chronic constipation: disorders of defecation (dyssynergy), STC, and NTC. Defecatory disorders can occur with either STC or NTC. Most patients can be treated without extensive testing. Systemic conditions and medications that aggravate constipation should be addressed.4 Diet, fluids, nonprescription medications, fiber supplements, osmotic agents, and stimulant cathartics can be effective but may challenge adherence. Refractory cases require specific testing and specialist referral. New drugs with novel mechanisms of action have shown promise.5,6 Biofeedback typically is recommended for defecatory disorders. Colorectal surgery is a last resort.

papers.title: Die Pollenallergie (Heuschnupfen)
papers.abstract: Sie spielen bei der Pollenallergie eine wesentlich geringere Rolle als beim Asthma bronchiale. Es wird berichtet, daß der erste Heuschnupfenanfall unter psychischer Einwirkung, z. B. durch Schreck oder Ärger, bei gleichzeitigem Vorhandensein des Allergens ausgelöst wurde. Es wird im Schrifttum aber auch über Fälle berichtet, bei denen durch rein psychische Einwirkung ohne das Vorhandensein des Allergens sich ein Anfall einstellte. Bei einem gegen Rosen überempfindlichen Heuschnupfenkranken von Mackenzie wurde angeblich ein Anfall durch den Anblick gut imitierter Papierrosen ausgelöst. Ein Patient von Urbach bekam Niesanfälle im Theater bei der Gartenszene im Faust. Nach unseren Erfahrungen gehören solche psychisch ausgelöste Anfälle beim Pollenallergiker zu den größten Seltenheiten. Wir haben sie bei keinem unserer Heuschnupfenkranken feststellen können. Mit ganz wenigen Einschränkungen kann man sagen, daß die krankhaften Erscheinungen nur dann auftreten, wenn der Pollenallergiker mit dem für ihn schädlichen Allergen in Berührung kommt. Man kann also den Heuschnupfen als ein klassisches Beispiel einer allergischen Erkrankung bezeichnen.
